results.title: Water erosion and waterlogging
results.creator_credit: Gerry North and Western Australia. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: Water erosion can result in the complete degradation of land by the removal of topsoils to expose infertile clay subsoils. The adoption of minimum tillage and other farm management techniques can lessen the risk of water erosion and improve farm productivity.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gerry North and Western Australia. Dept. of Agriculture
results.description: Water erosion can result in the complete degradation of land by the removal of topsoils to expose infertile clay subsoils. The adoption of minimum tillage and other farm management techniques can lessen the risk of water erosion and improve farm productivity.

results.title: Watching them write, seeing them learn: a kindergarten writing community at work
results.creator_credit: Brian Butler and Riverina College of Advanced Education. Literacy Centre
results.brief_description: Kindergarten children experiment with written language. There are no formal writing lessons and they are left free to learn by trial and error. Narrated by Barbara Kamler.

results.title: Watching ballet
results.creator_credit: Robert Bell, Tracy Ward and On Film
results.brief_description: Shows some of the rudiments of ballet training and performance. Allegra Kent and Jacques D’Amboise, with ballet students, demonstrate some fundamentals. Pianist: Jacques Pierre Martin.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Bell, Tracy Ward and On Film

results.title: War of the colossal beast
results.creator_credit: Bert I. Gordon and American International Pictures (AIP)
results.brief_description: In this sequel to “The Amazing colossal man” (Bert I. Gordon, 1957), the gigantic beast of the original is feared to have survived his almighty fall, and now quite deranged, to be posing an even greater threat. Incoherent and hideously disfigured, the monster is located in Mexico, but after thwarting the authorities attempts to tame him, goes on the rampage. Director and effects maestro Bert I. Gordon specialised in B-Grade 1950s horror, and does not disappoint here, even adding extra dazzle to the finale which is presented in colour.

results.title: War
results.brief_description: The narrator assume the role of the ‘universal soldier” who has been fighting for a million years and asks himself “why?” Asks and discuses questions like “have wars achieved anything?”, “what have soldiers and civilians died for?” and “why is every war bad?”
results.description: The narrator assume the role of the ‘universal soldier” who has been fighting for a million years and asks himself “why?” Asks and discuses questions like “have wars achieved anything?”, “what have soldiers and civilians died for?” and “why is every war bad?”

results.title: Walt Whitman's Leaves of grass
results.creator_credit: Helen Line, Francis R. Line and Line Films
results.brief_description: Uses the words of Walt Whitman, taken from his prose writings, diaries, note books and marginal manuscript notes, in presenting events in his life and in describing the influences which compelled him to write “Leaves of Grass”, his sympathetic observations of nature on Long Island and the people with whom he identified. Includes images of Long Island and New York in the 1960’s. Voice of Walt Whitman by Marvin Miller.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Helen Line, Francis R. Line and Line Films

results.title: Walt Disney Movie Viewer Cartridge [Snow White]
results.brief_description:
Walt Disney Movie Viewer
The first Movie Viewer was made in the USA in 1973 by Fisher Price. The British version was made by the Mettoy company. The viewer used Super 8 film and the actual clips were short pieces from real cartoon films. No technology was required to operate the viewer, not even batteries. The hand crank enabled the operator to view the film at any speed with the ability to go forwards or backwards at will.
